Alejo, R. Lago, M.A. Pefia, J.L.G. Fierro* lnstituto de Catdlisis y PetroleoqMmica, CSIC, Campus UAM, Cantoblanco, 28049 Madrid, Spain Received 13 November 1996; received in revised form 14 March 1997: accepted 14 March 1997 Abstract In this work Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Al203 catalysts have been studied for the partial oxidation of methanol with oxygen to produce hydrogen. These Cu-Zn based catalysts showed high activity for the partial oxidation of methanol and it was found that the catalytic activity is directly related to the copper metal surface area. In the series Cu-Zn with copper relative content of 20-70 wt%, the catalyst Cu40Zn6o (Cu 40 wt% and Zn 60 wt%) which showed the highest copper area gave the best results for the partial oxidation of methanol. The activation energies and TOF (turnover frequencies) varied with the Cu-Zn catalyst composition. For catalysts with low copper loading very high Ea and TOF were obtained (for Cu3oZnTo E,-482 k J/tool and TOF ca. 200 min-I at 497-499 K) whereas for higher copper contents the Ea and TOF decreased tending to constant values (for Cu7oZn3o Ea=71 kJ/mol and TOF= 160 min-t at 497-499 K). These results are discussed in terms of a possible effect of the Cu-ZnO interaction which depends on the catalyst composition. Catalytic experiments with Cu4oZn55A15 (Cu 40 wt%, Zn 55 wt% and A1 5 wt%) showed that the presence of aluminium has an inhibiting effect producing slightly lower methanol conversion. On the other hand, higher selectivities for H2 and CO2 were obtained with only traces of the undesirable carbon monoxide. Moreover, the A1 is very important for catalyst stability and life-time experiments showed that Cu4oZn55A15 is stable during the partial oxidation of methanol with no significant change in activity and selectivity even after 110 h operation at 503 K. The catalyst Cu40Zn6o with no A1, deactivates rapidly after 20 h reaction at 503 K. Experiments using N20 as oxidant showed higher activity to convert methanol but producing large amounts of H20 and CO. The impregnation of catalyst with Na produced similar effect increasing the selectivity for H20 and CO. The results presented seem to indicate that the copper metal is active for partial oxidation of methanol to H2 and CO2 whereas Cu+1 favour the formation of H20 and CO. Cu+2 as CuO shows very low activity for methanol conversion producing only CO2 and HaO. (~ 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords." Introduction The use of hydrogen gas as fuel for fuel cell mobile applications is hindered by problems of storage, *Corresponding author. Fax: +34 1 5854760; e-mail: jlgfierro@icp.csic.es safety, refueling, etc. These problems have led to a search for alternative hydrogen storage systems or alternative fuels from which H2 can be produced onboard. From the different liquid fuels considered methanol is an interesting alternative since it is the third commodity chemical after ethylene and ammo- nia with a production capacity in excess of 25 million 0926-860X/97/$17.00 (~, 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(97)001 12-9 282 L. Alejo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 162 (1997) 281-297 tons, much superior to the actual overall demand [1-4]. The production of hydrogen from methanol by steam reforming has been extensively studied over supported metallic catalysts such as copper [5-10], nickel [11], palladium [12], platinum [13] and rho- dium and platinum [ 14]. A limitation of steam reform- ing route is the endothermicity of the reaction: CH3OH + H20 ~ 3H2 + CO2, AH~98 = +49.4 kJ/mol (1) Moreover, the need to produce steam makes the process even more energy demanding. Huang and co- workers [15,16] studied the effect of the O2 addition during the steam reforming of methanol over copper- zinc catalysts. They reported that the presence of oxygen in the steam reforming enhances methanol conversion due to the occurrence of the partial oxida- tion of methanol (POM): CH3OH + 1/202 ~- 2H2 + CO2, AH~98 = -- 192.2 kJ/mol (2) The POM reaction to produce H2 offers some advantages over the steam reforming since it is an exothermic reaction, more favourable thermodynami- cally and uses 02 (air) instead of steam as oxidant, which make it more energy efficient. Moreover, it has been reported that the reaction rate of partial oxidation over copper catalysts is higher than the steam reform- ing reaction [16]. Another incentive comes from the simplicity of the POM reaction, which allows the development of compact hydrogen generators, parti- cularly for car engine purposes. Preliminary work reported by Kumar et al. from Argon National Laboratory [2] showed that among several catalysts with different metals and supports the system Cu/ZnO showed the more promising results. Apart from this general work, there is not so much information regarding the nature of copper species involved in the reaction and the role of the acid-base properties of the catalyst on catalyst performance and stability. Accordingly, this work was undertaken with the aim to design appropriate Cu-ZnO based catalyst for the POM reaction. Preliminary work carried out at the laboratory on the binary systems Cu-ZnO with different compositions showed that high hydrogen yields can be obtained, although catalyst stability is poor. To avoid this inconvenience, the ternary systems Cu-ZnO(A1203) have been prepared and used suc- cessfully in the POM reaction, exhibiting much better stability and life-time operation than the aluminium- flee counterparts. The role of basic promoters, such as MgO and Na20, and the introduction of N20 oxidant in the feed, instead of oxygen, have also been inves- tigated. The changes of catalyst structures either in the calcined and reduced stage has been monitored by X- ray diffraction, temperature-programmed reduction and oxidation, N20 adsorption-decomposition and photoelectron spectroscopy. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by adding a 1.25 M copper, zinc and aluminium nitrates (Merck, reagent grade) solutions (400ml) into a 0.25 M NazCO3 (Aldrich, reagent grade) solution under N2 atmosphere and vigorous stirring. During the precipitation the solution was kept at 333 K and pH ca. 8.5. The precipitate was then aged for 2.5 h and washed tho- roughly until the sodium content was lower than 0.2 ppm, as measured by atomic absorption spectro- photometry. The precipitate was then dried at 383 K for 12 h and calcined in air at 673 K for 12 h. The notation used in this work show the relative weight percentage of each metal in the catalyst, i.e. the catalyst Cu4oZn55A15 contains 40wt% of Cu, 55 wt% of Zn and 5 wt% of AI omitting the rest of the elements. An aliquot of the calcined catalyst Cu4oZn55A15 was impregnated either with NaNO3 (Merck, reagent grade) or with Mg(NO3)2 (Merck, reagent grade) solutions of appropriate concentration to yield 1 wt% of Na or Mg. The impregnates were then dried and calcined as above. The binary CuxZnl0o-x samples were prepared in a similar man- ner as for the ternary systems by adding the copper and zinc nitrates into the Na2CO3 solution. A high purity CuO sample (Spex) was used for quantitative reduc- tion measurements. 2.2. Experimental techniques All the metal contents in the catalysts were con- firmed by atomic absorption spectrophotometry by L. Alejo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 162 (1997) 281-297 283 solubilization using a concentrated HCI+HNO3 mix- ture in a microwave oven. Aliquots of the solution were diluted in order to reach a concentration of the elements in the calibration range of the instrument. The surface areas were calculated by the BET method from the N2 adsorption isotherms recorded in an ASAP 2000 equipment at 77 K and taking a value of 0.164rim2 for the cross-section of N2 molecule. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a Seifert 3000P diffractometer with a Ni-filtered CuKc~ (A=0.15418 nm) radiation, scan- ning 20 angles in the range 5-80 The Debye-Scher- rer equation was applied to the Cu (1 1 1) diffraction peak at 20=43.2to calculate the Cucrystallite size. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experi- ments of the calcined precursors were recorded on a Micromeritics apparatus model TPR/TPO 2900 fitted with a TC detector and controlled by a computer. Samples of 25 mg were pretreated in He at 393 K for 1 h and then the TPR experiment was run in a stream of H2 (10%) in N2 heating the catalyst at 10 K/min to 503 K, keeping this temperature for 1.5 h. Reduced catalysts according to this procedure were used for N20 decomposition adsorption experiments. N20 pulses (5 ~tl each) were dosed onto the reduced cata- lysts at 363 K until saturation. From these data, copper metal area was calculated according to the literature [17-19], assuming that the planes Cu(1 1 1), (1 1 0) and (1 0 0) which produce an average copper atom surface area of 7.41 x 10-2o m2 [19]. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were acquired with an ESCALAB 200R electron spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical electron analyser and a MgKc~ X-ray source (hv=1253.6eV, 1 eV=l.6020-wJ). The samples were mounted on a sample rod placed in a pretreatment chamber and outgassed under vacuum prior to transfer into the analysis chamber. The residual pressure in the ion- pumped analysis chamber was below 30-9Torr (1 Torr=133.33 Pa) during data acquisition. The C l s, O l s, Cu 2p3/2, Zn 2p3/2 and A1 2p (if present) were recorded. The binding energies were referenced to the C ls peak at a binding energy of 284.9 eV. The accuracy of the measured values was within .1 eV. Outgassed samples were then transferred to the pre- treatment chamber of the spectrometer and reduced in situ at 493 K for 1 h. The spectra of the reduced samples were recorded according to the above proce- dure. For the analyses by XRD and XPS after reaction the catalysts were all quenched to room temperature and immediately drenched in iso-octane under nitro- gen to avoid oxidation of exposed copper by exposure to atmosphere. The CULMM Auger peak was also recorded and the modified Auger parameter, C~A', calculated by the equation: CtA'=h.v+(KE CULMM-- KE Cu 2p3/2), where the difference in parentheses represents the difference between the kinetic energy of the Auger electron and the Cu 2p3/2 photoelectron. 2.3. Activity measurements The catalytic tests were carried out with 50 mg catalyst (0.20-0.30 ram) diluted with silicon carbide (500 mg) at atmospheric pressure between 473 and 503 K. Liquid methanol at a rate of 4 ml/h (0.12 mol/ h) was fed into the preheater by means of a liquid pump (Becton Dickinson). Synthetic air at a rate of 12 ml/min was adjusted by means of a Unit mass flow electronic controller. Under these conditions, the O2/CH3OH molar ratio in the feed was 0.06. In a few experiments, molecular oxygen (O2) was replaced by twice the amount of nitrous oxide (N20) since in a molar basis N20 can produce only half equivalents of oxygen. Most of the tests were performed on pre- reduced catalysts according to the same procedure than for XPS and N20 decomposition-quimisortion stu- dies. Blank activity experiments using ZnO alone (no Cu present) were carried out according to the above conditions. Additional experiments were also run on oxidic catalysts (no prereduction) following the same experimental procedure. In order to see if deactivation occurs for longer periods on-stream operation, two catalysts, Cu40Zn60 and Cu4oZn55A15, were tested in a period of 110 h for the partial oxidation of methanol at 503 K following the same experimental procedure than for catalyst screening. The reaction products were analysed on-line with a Varian 3400CX GC equipped with a TC detector and the columns Porapak Q and molecular sieve 13X. 3. Results 3.1. Catalytic activi~ of Cu-Zn systems The copper-zinc catalysts are very active for the partial oxidation of methanol to produce hydrogen and a typical reaction profile is shown in Fig. 5. It can be observed that at 488 K the reaction sets on and the rates of methanol and oxygen conversion strongly increase with the temperature to produce selectively H2 and CO2. The 02 conversion reaches 100% at 495 K. The rate of carbon monoxide production is very low throughout the temperature range studied and the H20 formation decreases for temperatures higher than 488 K. No other products such as formaldehyde, formic acid, methyl formate and dimethyl ether which are often formed by reactions of methanol in the presence of Cu catalysts could be detected under the reaction conditions employed [29]. The other Cu-ZnO catalysts with different compo- sitions showed similar reaction profiles. The effect of copper content on methanol conversion and H2 and CO2 formation can be seen in Fig. 6. Methanol con- version to H2 and CO2 increases with the copper content reaching a maximum with the catalyst Cu4oZn6o and decreasing for higher copper loadings. a relationship between the methanol partial oxidation and the copper metal surface area can also be clearly observed. Results of Argone laboratory [2] comparing silica and ZnO supported copper catalysts showed that the Cu/SiO2 catalysts are much less active and selective for the partial oxidation of methanol to H2. Extensive literature on methanol synthesis with Cu-ZnO cata- lysts point to a synergic effect between copper and zinc oxide [32--40]. Some of the explanations pro- posed for the synergic effect are: the catalytic site is located on the Cu-ZnO interface, modification of the electronic properties of copper by contact of Cu crystallites with zinc oxide, stabilization of active crystallographic planes of copper metal, stabilization of Cu+ species and a spillover phenomenon between Cu and ZnO. Fu and Somorjai [41] studied the metha- nol decomposition over a model catalyst based on zinc oxide on Cu(1 1 0) pretreated with oxygen. They L. Alejo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 162 (1997) 281-297 295 showed evidences that the zinc oxide promoted the oxidation of methoxide originated on the copper sur- face to a formate intermediate which can decompose to CO2 and H2. The addition of aluminium as A1203 to the Cu-ZnO methanol synthesis catalysts was found to be very important to produce a better dispersed copper phase and improve the catalyst stability by avoiding sinter- ing [34,40]. The effect of aluminium on the Cu-ZnO catalysts for the partial oxidation of methanol was investigate here. In the Cu-ZnO(A1203) catalyst series it was observed that the presence of aluminium had a strong effect on the reducibility of copper. In the presence of AI, the TPR peaks are shifted to higher temperatures, and under the pretreatment conditions part of the copper employed in the catalyst is not completely reduced. This behaviour may be related the formation of copper-aluminium compounds such as the spinel CuA1204. XPS analyses showed a Cu2+ component placed at high binding energies which might be related to Cu2+ ions in the spinel CuA1204. Moreover, for the calcined catalysts it was noted that, as the A1 content increases, the colour changes fi'om black for Cu4oZn55A15 to black-greenish for Cu4oZnasAl15 (the CuA1204 is green). On the other hand, no CuAI204 crystalline phase was observed by XRD analyses which suggests that if the spinel is formed it must be very well dispersed. It has been reported [42] that, for the CuAI204 spinel formation, calcination temperatures T>773 K are required which are higher than the calcination temperature 673 K used in this work. Somewhat lower temperatures than 773 K were reported by Friedman et al. [43] for the development of such a surface spinel CuAI204 on CuO/AI203 catalysts. In the ternary systems Cu4oZn60_xAlx there is an inhibitory effect of A1 for the partial oxidation of methanol, particularly for substitutions x=10 and 15. This inhibitory effect of Al has also been observed for methanol synthesis [44]. In the case of Cu40ZnsoAllo and Cu40Zn45Al15 the low activity for the partial oxidation of methanol may be related to the presence of part of the copper not reduced in the catalyst. Although the presence of aluminium decreases the activity of the catalysts it has an impor- tant effect in improving its stability. The catalyst Cu4oZn55Al5 was stabled for the partial oxidation of methanol at 503 K with no significant change in activity even after 110 h on-stream operation. How- ever, its Al-free counterpart Cu4oZn6o deactivates rapidly after 20 h reaction, showing a decrease in the selectivities for H2 and CO2 and parallel formation of significant amounts of CO. Moreover, the Cu40Zn55A15 catalyst is more selective for H2 and CO2 formation and only traces of CO were detected during the reaction. The ability of group IA alkali metals to promote methanol synthesis on Cu-Zn-A1 catalysts has been often reported in the literature [37,45--47]. It was proposed that the alkali metal effect is related to the stabilization of Cu+ species. It has also been reported that the presence of sodium may promote the ZnO crystallites sinterization diminishing the Cu- ZnO interaction [48], neutralize acid sites and change the electronic properties of metal catalysts [49]. For the partial oxidation of methanol the presence of 1 wt% of Na in the Cu4oZn55A15 catalyst also showed a remarkable effect on the catalytic properties favour- ing the formation of H20 and CO. Apparently, one of the effects of sodium is to inhibit the WGS equilibrium causing an increase in the selectivity for CO and H20. The addition of Mg, however, has essentially no effect on the partial oxidation of methanol. The replacement of O2 by N20 as oxidant increased the methanol conversion and the production of H20 and CO. It is very well known that N20 oxidizes Cu superficial to Cu+ at temperatures as low as 350 K [50]. XRD studies showed that in the oxidation with N20 carried out at 563 K the metallic copper in a Cu/ ZnO catalyst produces the phase Cu20 [51]. If the temperature is further increased the Cu20 is converted to CuO. Based on these results it seems reasonable to assume that in the oxidation of methanol with N20 the Cu+ species may have a significant contribution. It was observed that if the reaction temperature is increased to 498 K the methanol conversion and the formation of CO and H20 decrease rapidly. The production of H2 and CO2 also drops but to a lesser extent. It is not clear why this sudden change in behaviour happened but it can be speculated that it might be related to a transformation of Cu+-O species to Cu2+-O caused by the increase of the temperature. The catalytic effect produced by using N20 oxidant is similar to the addition of Na to the catalyst, i.e., preferential formation of CO and H20. If the role of Na is to stabilize Cu+ as it has been proposed in the 296 L. Alejo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 162 (1997) 281-297 literature, then these two experiments are indicating that Cu+ species are active to convert methanol but produce large amounts of H20 and CO. The mechanism of the partial oxidation of methanol can be very complex. First, there might be several processes catalysed by copper present under the reac- tion conditions, such as methanol steam reforming (Eq. (1)), partial oxidation (Eq.(2)), methanol decomposition, water gas shift and other oxidations: CO + 1/202 ~ CO2 (4) H2 + 1/202 ~ H20 (5) Preliminary experiments showed that at least part of H2 and CO2 are not formed by the partial oxidation of methanol in a single step but are produced as second- ary products by other reactions. It is likely, for instance, that the WGS reaction contributes to the formation of H2 and CO2 at the expense of CO and H20. The O2/CH3OH molecular ratio should be very important in determining the product distribution. An excess of methanol (O2/CH3OH <0.5) should favour the partial products formation since if H20 is pro- duced by combustion it would further react with methanol via steam reform to H2 and CO2. On the other hand, if methanol is in a large excess the decomposition producing CO may be significant. Therefore, it is envisaged that the O2/CH3OH molar ratio near 0.5 should give optimum yields of H2. 5. Conclusions Copper-zinc catalysts display great activity and selectivity for the conversion of methanol to H2 and CO2, and their activity is related to the copper metal surface area. Metallic copper is produced by pre- reduction of the catalyst prior to reaction, and it is preserved under reaction conditions due to the redu- cing reaction environment. The maximum of activity is obtained for a relative composition of Cu40Zn60, which exhibits the maximum copper metal area. How- ever, the nature of the active centres changes with the copper content, since both TOF and apparent activa- tion energy depend on the catalyst composition. This change of the active centres is related to a modification of the CuZnO interface by altering dispersion and particle size of copper. A synergetic effect, similar to that occurring in the methanol synthesis, is suggested to be involved in the partial oxidation of methanol. Incorporation of aluminium oxide to these Cu-ZnO catalysts leads to an inhibitory effect of methanol conversion, but with two important beneficial conse- quences: (i), the selectivity to H2 and CO2 production increases, with only traces of CO; and (ii) the stability of the catalyst activity improves. Finally, experiments using N20 as oxidant and Na incorporation to the base catalysts allows to conclude that Cu+ species gener- ated in both processes is active for the formation of CO and H20, whereas Cu2+ species favours the methanol deep combustion to CO2 and H20. Fax: +34 1 5854760 In this work Cu ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts have been studied for the partial oxidation of methanol with oxygen to produce hydrogen. These CuZn based catalysts showed high activity for the partial oxidation of methanol and it was found that the catalytic activity is directly related to the copper metal surface area. In the series CuZn with copper relative content of 20–70 wt%, the catalyst Cu40Zn60 (Cu 40 wt% and Zn 60 wt%) which showed the highest copper area gave the best results for the partial oxidation of methanol. The activation energies and TOF (turnover frequencies) varied with the CuZn catalyst composition. For catalysts with low copper loading very high E a and TOF were obtained (for Cu30Zn70 E a=482 kJ/mol and TOF ca. 200 min−1 at 497–499 K) whereas for higher copper contents the E a and TOF decreased tending to constant values (for Cu70Zn30 E a=71 kJ/mol and TOF=160 min−1 at 497–499 K). These results are discussed in terms of a possible effect of the CuZnO interaction which depends on the catalyst composition. Catalytic experiments with Cu40Zn55Al5 (Cu 40 wt%, Zn 55 wt% and Al 5 wt%) showed that the presence of aluminium has an inhibiting effect producing slightly lower methanol conversion. On the other hand, higher selectivities for H2 and CO2 were obtained with only traces of the undesirable carbon monoxide. Moreover, the Al is very important for catalyst stability and life-time experiments showed that Cu40Zn55Al5 is stable during the partial oxidation of methanol with no significant change in activity and selectivity even after 110 h operation at 503 K. The catalyst Cu40Zn60 with no Al, deactivates rapidly after 20 h reaction at 503 K. Experiments using N2O as oxidant showed higher activity to convert methanol but producing large amounts of H2O and CO. The impregnation of catalyst with Na produced similar effect increasing the selectivity for H2O and CO. The results presented seem to indicate that the copper metal is active for partial oxidation of methanol to H2 and CO2 whereas Cu+1 favour the formation of H2O and CO. Cu+2 as CuO shows very low activity for methanol conversion producing only CO2 and H2O. coredata.dc:description: In this work Cu ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts have been studied for the partial oxidation of methanol with oxygen to produce hydrogen. These CuZn based catalysts showed high activity for the partial oxidation of methanol and it was found that the catalytic activity is directly related to the copper metal surface area. In the series CuZn with copper relative content of 20–70 wt%, the catalyst Cu40Zn60 (Cu 40 wt% and Zn 60 wt%) which showed the highest copper area gave the best results for the partial oxidation of methanol. The activation energies and TOF (turnover frequencies) varied with the CuZn catalyst composition. For catalysts with low copper loading very high E a and TOF were obtained (for Cu30Zn70 E a=482 kJ/mol and TOF ca. 200 min−1 at 497–499 K) whereas for higher copper contents the E a and TOF decreased tending to constant values (for Cu70Zn30 E a=71 kJ/mol and TOF=160 min−1 at 497–499 K). These results are discussed in terms of a possible effect of the CuZnO interaction which depends on the catalyst composition. Catalytic experiments with Cu40Zn55Al5 (Cu 40 wt%, Zn 55 wt% and Al 5 wt%) showed that the presence of aluminium has an inhibiting effect producing slightly lower methanol conversion. On the other hand, higher selectivities for H2 and CO2 were obtained with only traces of the undesirable carbon monoxide. Moreover, the Al is very important for catalyst stability and life-time experiments showed that Cu40Zn55Al5 is stable during the partial oxidation of methanol with no significant change in activity and selectivity even after 110 h operation at 503 K. The catalyst Cu40Zn60 with no Al, deactivates rapidly after 20 h reaction at 503 K. Experiments using N2O as oxidant showed higher activity to convert methanol but producing large amounts of H2O and CO. The impregnation of catalyst with Na produced similar effect increasing the selectivity for H2O and CO. The results presented seem to indicate that the copper metal is active for partial oxidation of methanol to H2 and CO2 whereas Cu+1 favour the formation of H2O and CO. Cu+2 as CuO shows very low activity for methanol conversion producing only CO2 and H2O.
coredata.dc:title: Partial oxidation of methanol to produce hydrogen over CuZn-based catalysts
